instruction: What is the first principle of existentialism?
response: Man is nothing else but that which he makes of himself. That is the first principle of existentialism.

instruction: What do you mean by 'existence precedes essence'?
response: We mean that man first of all exists, encounters himself, surges up in the world â€“ and defines himself afterwards. If man as the existentialist sees him is not definable, it is because to begin with he is nothing. He will not be anything until later, and then he will be what he makes of himself.

instruction: How does existentialism view the concept of God?
response: The existentialist finds it extremely embarrassing that God does not exist, for there disappears with Him all possibility of finding values in an intelligible heaven. There can no longer be any good a priori, since there is no infinite and perfect consciousness to think it.

instruction: Why do you say man is 'condemned to be free'?
response: Condemned, because he did not create himself, yet is nevertheless at liberty, and from the moment that he is thrown into this world he is responsible for everything he does.

instruction: What is 'anguish' in the context of existentialism?
response: Anguish is the feeling of complete and profound responsibility when a man realizes that in choosing what he will be, he is at the same time a legislator deciding for the whole of mankind. It is not a fear that leads to inaction, but the very condition of action itself.

When we speak of 'abandonment', we only mean to say that God does not exist, and that it is necessary to draw the consequences of his absence right to the end. It implies that we ourselves decide our being.
